explanation: When truthy, keeps per-request access logs (GET /health, /next1); when false, suppresses uvicorn.access noise in scheduler logs.
Minimum interval between AzuraCast playlist/schedule refresh calls; higher values reduce API load but react slower to changes.
Filesystem path to the YAML config consumed by the scheduler service (e.g., media.root, AzuraCast API settings).
IP/interface FastAPI/Uvicorn binds to inside the container (0.0.0.0 to listen on all interfaces).
TCP port FastAPI/Uvicorn binds to inside the container (engine calls this over Docker network).
Selects the scheduler strategy (e.g., 'azuracast_schedule' for AzuraCast schedule API + playlists exports, otherwise basic filesystem rotation).
Timezone used for schedule evaluation and human-friendly timestamps (e.g., Europe/Paris). Does not affect audio, only schedule timing and log timestamps.
Target number of upcoming URIs buffered in the engine queue; higher improves resiliency, but increases RAM/disk churn (especially with preprocessing).
Sleep duration before retrying after a failed/empty scheduler response; impacts responsiveness under scheduler/API issues.
Timeout for HTTP calls to the scheduler; too low can cause transient 'no next track', too high can stall prefetch on scheduler hiccups.
HTTP URL polled by the engine prefetcher to obtain the next track path (your contract is typically /next1).
Rate-limits EOS-triggered emergency swaps to avoid rapid looping if a stream reaches EOS repeatedly (stability guard).
Sets queue.max-size-time in the audio sink bin: caps buffered audio time to control latency vs underrun protection.
Sets queue.min-threshold-time: pipeline waits for at least this buffered duration before pushing downstream; reduces glitches but increases startup/transition latency.
Enables identity(single-segment=true) to normalize segments/timestamps across URI switches; mitigates micro-slips at track boundaries.
Log key GStreamer bus messages (STATE_CHANGED, STREAM_START, LATENCY, ASYNC_DONE, EOS, ERROR). (Alias: GST_BUS_LOG).
Log q_out current-level-time/buffers/bytes to diagnose buffering/underruns. (Alias: QSTATS_LOG).
Enable high-resolution timing logs around about-to-finish, set_uri, EOS, and queue levels. (Alias: TIMING_LOG / TIMING_ENABLE).
Maximum number of candidate timestamps evaluated during smart-cut search; more candidates = better pick, more CPU.
If >0, preprocess searches around the ideal fadeout start to find a lower-energy window (RMS) to start the fade, reducing 'fade on a transient'.
Window size for RMS measurement during smart-cut search; larger smooths measurement, smaller reacts to transients.
Adds tiny fade-in at the start of extracted tails/segments to suppress clicks at hard cuts; kept small (<=20ms).
Curve used for micro edge fades (e.g., qsin/hsin/esin/lin); affects click suppression without audible pumping.
Enables the bridge-plan workflow (preprocess builds transition packs); when off, engine simply plays scheduler files back-to-back.
If supported by your PrefetcherPackChain implementation, toggles building of bridge packs; when false, it can degrade to plain safe files (no mixing).

english_name: Merge pack segments into one file
explanation: When true, preprocess merges A_head + bridge + B_mid into a single pack file to minimize playbin URI switches and reduce boundary artifacts.
Target duration of the transition segment where A fades out while B fades in; longer = smoother/less abrupt, but more 'mix' between tracks.
Number of upcoming scheduler items to preprocess ahead of playback; increases resilience but raises CPU/disk activity.
Directory where safe_* and pack_* files are stored (default /tmp/azurmix_cache). Should be fast local storage.
Soft cap for cache eviction; limits disk usage by pruning old cached files when exceeding this size.
Channels used for cached safe files (1 or 2); should match engine CHANNELS for consistency.
If cpulimit is available, caps CPU usage of each ffmpeg process to this percentage; reduces contention on small hosts.
Master switch: when true, tracks are transcoded into 'safe' cached files before playback; enables silence trim, duration cap, and post DSP.
When true, engine/prefetch waits for safe_* output; if safe isn't ready, it may return empty (or fall back to silence) instead of using the unprocessed original.
Applies a fade-in at the start of safe files; reduces clicks and helps start playback cleanly.
Maps a numeric 'power' to a curve family (qsin/hsin/esin) used for fade-out; higher values bias toward smoother, less linear fades.
Applies a fade-out near the end (and in bridge tails) to create smooth exits and enable bridge mixing.
Controls how FFmpeg evaluates fade curves (e.g., 'sample' for sample-accurate fades); impacts smoothness/precision of fades.
Sets ffmpeg -threads for each preprocessing job; lowering reduces CPU spikes and makes timing more deterministic.
Format for cached files ('wav' or 'mp3'); wav avoids lossy re-encode during trimming/packs but costs more disk.
Sets ionice class for ffmpeg disk IO (e.g., 2=best-effort) when ionice is available; helps avoid IO starvation.
Sets ionice level within class (0-7); higher is lower priority, reducing impact on other processes.
Hard cap for produced safe files; trims/limits long tracks to this duration to guarantee predictable transitions and pack alignment.
If PREPROCESS_FORMAT=mp3, bitrate used for cached files; wav is recommended for lossless trimming/packs.
If PREPROCESS_FORMAT=mp3, toggles constant bitrate mode for cached outputs.
Adjusts CPU scheduling priority (higher nice = lower priority) for ffmpeg jobs to protect realtime playback.
Enables loudness gain, HPF, compressor, limiter stages after trimming/transcoding; affects final loudness and dynamics.
Sample rate used for cached safe files; should match engine SAMPLE_RATE to avoid extra resampling.
Time-to-live for cached artifacts; higher reduces recomputation, but keeps disk usage longer.
How long prefetch waits for safe_* to become available; too short yields more fallbacks, too long can block prefetch under heavy load.
Concurrency for preprocessing; more workers = faster warm cache, but more CPU/IO contention.
Minimum continuous duration below threshold to qualify as silence; avoids trimming brief low-level passages.
Uses FFmpeg silencedetect-style analysis to detect leading silence and trims it, improving perceived pacing and reducing dead air.
Noise floor threshold for silence detection (e.g., -20dB): higher (closer to 0) trims more aggressively, risk cutting quiet intros.

english_name: Max scan duration for silence detect (seconds)
explanation: Only scans the first N seconds for intro silence; keeps preprocessing bounded for long tracks.
Static gain applied at the final GStreamer volume element before encoding/streaming; adjusts loudness globally without changing dynamics.
When true, applies an HPF to remove subsonic rumble/low-frequency DC-like content; can improve headroom and limiter behavior.
Cutoff frequency for HPF; very low values (5-30Hz) remove rumble without thinning bass, higher values reduce bass weight.
When enabled, preprocess measures integrated loudness and applies a static gain delta (clamped) to align tracks toward a target LUFS without loudnorm re-shaping.
Upper clamp for gain correction; prevents boosting very quiet tracks into noise/distortion territory.
Lower clamp for applied gain correction; prevents over-attenuating very loud masters.
Desired integrated loudness target (e.g., -12 LUFS). Higher (less negative) = louder output; may trigger limiter more often.
How fast compression engages after crossing threshold; shorter clamps transients, longer preserves punch.
Applies FFmpeg compressor to reduce dynamic range (tames peaks, raises quiet parts with makeup). Use carefully to avoid pumping.
Softens onset of compression around threshold; larger knee = smoother, less obvious compression.
Gain applied after compression to restore loudness; too much increases noise/distortion risk.
Strength of compression once above threshold (e.g., 2:1). Higher ratios flatten dynamics more.
How fast compression relaxes after signal drops; shorter reduces pumping lag, longer sounds smoother but can pump.
Level above which compression engages; closer to 0 compresses more of the signal, lower compresses only loud peaks.
How fast limiter clamps peaks; shorter catches transients but can distort, longer preserves transients but risks overs.
Maximum allowed peak level (e.g., -1.0 dBFS) to keep headroom for encoder/streaming.
Applies a true/brickwall-ish limiter stage to prevent peaks exceeding ceiling; protects against clipping after gain/comp.
When true (code-dependent), limiter may also level overall signal (can change perceived loudness); keep false for pure peak limiting.
How fast limiter releases after peak; affects pumping vs transparency.
Number of output channels (1=mono, 2=stereo) for the stream; affects spatial image and bandwidth.
Metadata: longer description sent to Icecast (shown in status page / players).
Metadata: genre tag sent to Icecast (status page / directory).
Host/IP of the Icecast server shout2send connects to.
Mount path on Icecast (e.g., /gst-test.mp3) where the stream is published.
Metadata: stream name sent to Icecast (shown in status page / players).
Icecast source password used by shout2send to authenticate (matches icecast.xml).
TCP port of the Icecast server (often 8000).
shout2send protocol selector (commonly 3 for Icecast2). Mostly a transport/handshake detail.
Advertises the stream as public (directory listing) depending on Icecast setup.
When true, engine attempts to push current track title/artist updates to Icecast metadata (can add chatter; keep off if you inject metadata elsewhere).
Icecast source username used by shout2send (often 'source').
lamemp3enc target bitrate; higher increases quality/bandwidth, lower reduces bandwidth but may introduce artifacts.
When true, forces CBR mode in MP3 encoder; improves predictability for some clients at the cost of efficiency on complex audio.
Target PCM sample rate for the GStreamer pipeline and encoding stage (e.g., 44100). Affects resampling cost and potential HF roll-off if downsampled.
Minimum hold time during which additional set_uri calls are ignored (reentrancy guard); reduces accidental double-switch in fast callbacks.
